description: This lecture course and a companion laboratory course (MEAM 147) build upon the concepts of Newtonian (classical) mechanics and their application to engineered systems. This course introduces students to mechanical principles that are the foundation of upper-level engineering courses including MEAM 210 and 211. The three major parts of this course are: I. Vector Mechanics; II. Statics and Structures; and III. Kinematics and Dynamics. Topics include: vector analysis, statics of rigid bodies, introduction to deformable bodies, friction, kinematics of motion, work and energy, and dynamics of particles. Case studies will be introduced, and the role of Newtonian mechanics in emerging applications including bio- and nano- technologies will be discussed.
name: INTRO TO MECHANICS

values.comments:
This lecture course and a companion laboratory course (MEAM 147) build upon
the concepts of Newtonian (classical) mechanics and their application to engineered
systems. This course introduces students to mechanical principles that are the foundation
of upper-level engineering courses including MEAM 210 and 211. The course focuses
on vector mechanics; statics and structures; and kinematics and dynamics. Topics
include vector analysis, statics of rigid bodies, introduction to deformable bodies,
friction, kinematics of motion, work and energy, and dynamics of particles.
A student stated “The online homework seems like busy work, but the hand in
problems are a good indicator if what shows up on.” Students stated that this course
taught material very close to Physics 150 with an engineering focus, but students stated
that it was “easier and better” than Physics 150. Students stated the lab course reinforced
the material in this course quite well.
Students stated that Carpick was “engaging.” Students appreciated the numerous
in-class demonstrations. Students stated that Carpick and all the TAs were very willing
to help students help all the material. “Helpful” and “friendly” were two common
adjectives to describe Carpick. A student stated, “The course is a lot of work, and it can
be challenging but the professors and TAs are there to make sure people do well and are
always available. They basically double the amount of office hours in the week before an
exam, which is very helpful.”
This course is primarily meant for freshman engineers interested in pursuing a
Mechanical Engineering degree. Students definitely recommended that all engineers take
this course instead of Physics 150 if their major gives them the option.
